snippet: Retail sales were down 0.4 percent in March as higher Social Security taxes and the slow pace of hiring caused consumers to spend less. Consumer confidence also fell.
abstract: Commerce Department reports that retail sales declined by a seasonally adjusted 0.4 percent in March, following 1 percent gain in February; decline suggests that higher taxes and weak hiring made some consumers cautious about spending.
lead_paragraph: Retail sales were down 0.4 percent in March as higher Social Security taxes and the slow pace of hiring caused consumers to spend less. Consumer confidence also fell.

headline.main: March Retail Sales Fell as Consumers Cut Back
headline.print_headline: March Retail Sales Fell As Consumers Cut Back
